page.title: 04UNEMPLOYMENT (LOCAL)
page.content: Thomas Ryder established in 1865 making textile rollers supplying the world. In 1928 began to make machine tools for car manufacturers. A rapid expansion in car manufacture in 1950 resulted in Ryder's expansion. For 20 years this family business was successful until cash flow problems began and there was a dramatic increase in Japanese car imports. Vauxhall and British Leyland reduced their orders to Ryder's who were taken over by an American company in 1981. The company finally ceased production, moved to Derby and left hundreds of local men unemployed. A small company set up in one of the buildings is now employing a previous floor manager as a floor sweeper.
